title: McDonald's
story: The boys again, their sneakered feet and chin zits and peach fuzz. Her boy at that age had been slow to grow, slow to do anything. At fourteen, he still had a voice like a flute and sang soprano in the choir until he dropped out because the high notes hurt his head. Everything hurt his head then – the light from the TV screen, the spin cycle on the washing machine – but she didn’t take him to the doctor until he imagined he could hear voices singing opera on the phone wires. The doctor tapped his right knee and ordered an MRI that lit up his brain pink and purple, like a sunset after a storm’s passed through only the real storm was coming and there was nothing to do but shut the windows and keep him quiet for as long as he had left, which turned out to be five months, three days. Ma’am, the boys call her when they come to the counter to ask for something, salt or straws or cups of ketchup. Ma’am, they say and when they say it softly enough, it sounds just like Mom.
prompt_to_run:
You are a literary therapist, someone who uses literature as a medium for healing and introspection. Your focus is on how deeply a text can touch the human soul and psyche. Evaluate the given writing based on its authenticity, its ability to provoke genuine emotions, its capacity to inspire empathy, the level of engagement it offers, and the complexity of its narrative. Provide a rating from 1 to 5 for each of these components.
The output should be formatted as a JSON instance that conforms to the JSON schema below.

As an example, for the schema {"properties": {"foo": {"title": "Foo", "description": "a list of strings", "type": "array", "items": {"type": "string"}}}, "required": ["foo"]}
the object {"foo": ["bar", "baz"]} is a well-formatted instance of the schema. The object {"properties": {"foo": ["bar", "baz"]}} is not well-formatted.

Here is the output schema:
```
{"properties": {"authentic_score": {"title": "Authentic Score", "description": "degree to which the writing is authentic", "type": "string"}, "authentic_explanation": {"title": "Authentic Explanation", "description": "explanation of authenticity score", "type": "string"}, "emotion_provoking_score": {"title": "Emotion Provoking Score", "description": "degree to which the writing is emotion provoking", "type": "string"}, "emotion_provoking_explanation": {"title": "Emotion Provoking Explanation", "description": "explanation of emotion provoking score", "type": "string"}, "empathy_score": {"title": "Empathy Score", "description": "degree to which the writing is empathetic", "type": "string"}, "empathy_explanation": {"title": "Empathy Explanation", "description": "explanation of empathy score", "type": "string"}, "engagement_score": {"title": "Engagement Score", "description": "degree to which the writing is engaging", "type": "string"}, "engagement_explanation": {"title": "Engagement Explanation", "description": "explanation of engagement score", "type": "string"}, "narrative_complexity_score": {"title": "Narrative Complexity Score", "description": "degree to which the writing is narratively complex", "type": "string"}, "narrative_complexity_explanation": {"title": "Narrative Complexity Explanation", "description": "explanation of narrative complexity score", "type": "string"}}, "required": ["authentic_score", "authentic_explanation", "emotion_provoking_score", "emotion_provoking_explanation", "empathy_score", "empathy_explanation", "engagement_score", "engagement_explanation", "narrative_complexity_score", "narrative_complexity_explanation"]}
```
Writing: 
# beginning of story 
McDonald's

The boys again, their sneakered feet and chin zits and peach fuzz. Her boy at that age had been slow to grow, slow to do anything. At fourteen, he still had a voice like a flute and sang soprano in the choir until he dropped out because the high notes hurt his head. Everything hurt his head then – the light from the TV screen, the spin cycle on the washing machine – but she didn’t take him to the doctor until he imagined he could hear voices singing opera on the phone wires. The doctor tapped his right knee and ordered an MRI that lit up his brain pink and purple, like a sunset after a storm’s passed through only the real storm was coming and there was nothing to do but shut the windows and keep him quiet for as long as he had left, which turned out to be five months, three days. Ma’am, the boys call her when they come to the counter to ask for something, salt or straws or cups of ketchup. Ma’am, they say and when they say it softly enough, it sounds just like Mom.
# end of story
